title: Multi-Step Cooking — Vegetable Soup from Scratch
description: The child follows a multi-step recipe to prepare vegetable soup, including washing, peeling, chopping, and simmering. This culminating cooking project integrates all previously learned food preparation skills into a single, satisfying meal.
instructions:
1. Review the recipe together: vegetable soup with carrots, celery, potatoes, and onion.
2. Wash hands thoroughly.
3. Wash all vegetables under running water.
4. Demonstrate peeling carrots and potatoes with a child-safe peeler.
5. Child peels remaining vegetables.
6. Demonstrate dicing: cut peeled vegetable in half, then into strips, then into small cubes.
7. Child chops celery, carrots, and potatoes into small pieces (adult handles onion if child is sensitive).
8. Heat olive oil in a pot (adult manages the stove). Child adds vegetables.
9. Add water or broth to cover the vegetables.
10. Season with a pinch of salt and herbs (thyme, bay leaf).
11. Simmer for 20-25 minutes (use a timer — child sets it).
12. While soup simmers, clean up all prep dishes and wipe counters.
13. Taste, adjust seasoning, serve in bowls.
14. Child serves soup to family members.

slides.heading: Multi-Step Cooking
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the title for our super fun cooking adventure. Today, we get to make yummy vegetable soup all by ourselves, from the very beginning!

items: Olive oil, salt, thyme, bay leaf
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all vegetables, tools, and ingredients on the counter. Child puts on apron and washes hands.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these cool things we need for our soup! We have colorful vegetables like carrots and potatoes, a special peeler and knife for chopping, a big pot for cooking, and yummy things like oil and salt to make it taste good. Let's ask a grown-up to help us gather everything and put on our special cooking apron!

slides.text: 'Today we are making real soup from scratch! Look at our recipe. First we wash, then peel, then chop, then cook. That is four big steps!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us our plan for making the soup! First, we'll wash everything so it's nice and clean, then we'll carefully peel the vegetables, next we'll chop them into tiny pieces, and finally, we'll cook them all up. It’s like a yummy recipe adventure with four big steps!

slides.text: 'Wash each vegetable under the water. Feel the dirt come off! Now let us peel the carrots and potatoes.' Demonstrate slow, even strokes with the peeler, always peeling away from the body.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let’s get our vegetables super clean! We'll put them under the water and rub them to wash off any dirt, just like giving them a bath. Then, we'll use this special peeler to take off the skin from the carrots and potatoes, moving it away from us so we stay safe.

slides.text: 'Now we chop. Remember: flat side down, fingers curled like a cat paw, cut slowly.' Demonstrate dicing a carrot into small cubes. Child chops remaining vegetables.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time for chopping! Remember to put the vegetable flat on the board, curl your fingers like a little bear paw, and cut slowly. We’ll make all the vegetables into tiny, yummy cubes that will be perfect for our soup. You are doing such a great job chopping!

slides.text: 'We add oil to the pot, then our vegetables. Listen to them sizzle! Stir gently. Now add the broth and seasonings. Set the timer for 25 minutes.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We’re putting everything together now! First, we’ll add a little bit of oil to the big pot, then carefully put in all our chopped veggies and listen to them sizzle! Next, we’ll add some water or broth and a sprinkle of special herbs, and then we’ll set our timer to cook for 25 minutes.

slides.prompt: While the soup simmers, wash and dry all the cutting boards, knives, and prep dishes. Wipe down the counter. Set the table with bowls, spoons, and napkins for your family.
slides.mascot_explanation: While our soup is cooking, we have some important jobs to do! We need to wash all the dishes we used for chopping and wipe the counter so everything is nice and clean. Then, we can set the table with bowls, spoons, and napkins for our family to eat our yummy soup!

slides.text: Taste your soup! Ladle it carefully into bowls and serve to your family. You made a whole meal from start to finish!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow a multi-step recipe with minimal adult intervention, managing wash-peel-chop-cook sequence?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, the soup is ready to taste! Let’s carefully use the ladle to put some soup into our bowls, and then we can share it with our family. You did it! You made a whole, delicious meal from start to finish, all by yourself!

parent_notes: This is a culminating practical life experience that integrates months of skill-building: pouring, cutting, peeling, measuring, cleaning, serving. In Montessori, cooking is not just a fun activity but genuine, purposeful work that builds independence, sequencing, and executive function. Allow the child to do as much as possible — your role is safety supervisor, not chef. If the child is sensitive to onion fumes, you may chop the onion yourself. Emphasize the full cycle: planning, preparation, cooking, serving, and cleanup. The child should feel the deep satisfaction of feeding others.

title: Compound Words — Combining Two Words into One
description: The child discovers that two small words can combine to make one larger word. Using picture cards and the moveable alphabet, the child builds compound words like sunflower, rainbow, and butterfly.
instructions:
1. 'I have a fun word puzzle for you today! Listen: sun + flower = sunflower! Two words joined together!'
2. Show picture cards: picture of sun, picture of flower, picture of sunflower.
3. Build 'sun' and 'flower' separately with the moveable alphabet, then push them together to make 'sunflower.'
4. Repeat with: rain + bow, butter + fly, cup + cake, book + shelf.
5. Child builds each word independently.
6. Challenge: give the child just the compound word and ask them to find the two words hiding inside.
7. Read compound words from a prepared list.
8. Child writes 3 favorite compound words in their journal.
materials_needed: Compound word picture cards (sun/flower/sunflower, rain/bow/rainbow, etc.)

slides.heading: Compound Words
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Compound Words," and that means we're going to learn how two little words can hug each other and become one big, special word! Isn't that neat?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare picture card sets. Lay out the moveable alphabet on the work mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special tools ready for our word adventure! We have these fun letter tiles called the moveable alphabet, a mat to work on, and some pictures that will help us. We'll also need our journal and a pencil for later!

slides.text: 'Some big words are really two small words stuck together! Listen: SUN... FLOWER... SUNFLOWER! Can you hear the two words hiding inside?'
slides.mascot_explanation: I have a super fun word game for you! Listen closely: SUN... and FLOWER... when we put them together, they make SUNFLOWER! Can you hear the two little words hiding inside that big word?

slides.text: Show picture cards. Build 'sun' with the moveable alphabet. Build 'flower' next to it. Push them together. 'Now it says sunflower!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we'll use our letter tiles to make that big word! Let's find the letters for 'sun' and put them together, then find the letters for 'flower' right next to it. See? When we push them close, they make one big word: sunflower!

slides.text: 'Let us try more! RAIN + BOW = ?' Child builds each pair: rainbow, butterfly, cupcake, bookshelf, starfish, bedroom.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play again! We'll take the word 'rain' and the word 'bow' and put them together to make 'rainbow'! We'll do this for lots of fun words like butterfly and cupcake!

slides.text: 'Now I will say a big word and YOU find the two words hiding inside: toothbrush... what two words do you hear?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a word detective! I'll say a big word, and you have to listen very carefully to find the two smaller words hiding inside, like in the word 'toothbrush'!

slides.prompt: Build 5 compound words with the moveable alphabet. For each one, first build the two small words, then push them together. Write your 3 favorites in your journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: You're doing so great building these words! Let's build five more by putting the two little words together, and then pick your three favorites to draw in your journal. You've got this!

slides.text: Compound words are everywhere! Look for them in your books today. How many can you spot?
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the two component words in a compound word and build at least 4 compound words independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: We found so many amazing compound words today! Now, let's look for them in your books – they are hiding everywhere! You did such a fantastic job putting words together like a super word builder!

parent_notes: Compound words are a wonderful bridge between decoding and word analysis. They help children see that long, intimidating words can be broken into familiar parts. This skill transfers directly to future work with prefixes and suffixes. Make it playful — children love the idea of words hiding inside other words. You can extend this throughout the day: 'We are having breakfast — what two words do you hear?' Keep a running list on the refrigerator of compound words the child discovers.

title: Clock — Quarter-Hour and Five-Minute Intervals
description: Building on hour and half-hour reading, the child learns to read quarter-past and quarter-to on an analog clock, then progresses to counting by fives around the clock face.
instructions:
1. Review: show 3:00 and 3:30 on the demonstration clock. Child reads them.
2. 'The minute hand has gone halfway around. What if it only goes a quarter of the way?'
3. Show 3:15. 'This is quarter past three. The minute hand points to the 3.'
4. Show 3:45. 'This is quarter to four. The minute hand points to the 9. We are almost at the next hour!'
5. Practice reading quarter-past and quarter-to with different hours.
6. 'Now let us count by fives around the clock!' Point to each number: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, 55, 60.
7. Show various times (2:05, 7:20, 10:35) and have the child read them.
8. Child sets the clock to given times.

slides.heading: Telling Time
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our special lesson all about telling time! We are going to learn about times like "quarter past" and how to count the minutes super fast.

slides.setup_instructions: Set both clocks to 12:00 to start. Have the skip-counting strip visible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We need our big demonstration clock and your own little clock so we can practice together. We also have a special number strip to help us count the minutes.

slides.text: 'You already know o'clock and half past. Remember, when the minute hand goes all the way around, that is 60 minutes — one hour. Halfway is 30 minutes.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about the hour hand and the minute hand? When the minute hand goes all the way around, it's a whole hour, and when it's halfway, it's 30 minutes!

slides.text: 'What about a quarter of the way? That is 15 minutes!' Show 3:15. 'This is quarter past three. The minute hand points to the 3 — and 3 means 15 minutes.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at when the minute hand is just a little bit past the middle. See how it points to the 3? That means it's "quarter past" the hour, like quarter past three!

slides.text: 'Three quarters of the way is 45 minutes!' Show 3:45. 'This is quarter to four — only 15 more minutes until 4 o'clock.'
slides.mascot_explanation: And when the minute hand is almost all the way around, pointing to the 9, it's called "quarter to" the next hour. It's like we're getting ready for the next big number!

slides.text: 'Each number on the clock means 5 minutes. Let us count by fives: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, 55, 60!' Point to each number as you count.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a fun way to count! Each big number on the clock is like a group of 5 minutes, so we can count by fives all the way around: 5, 10, 15, and so on!

slides.prompt: Set your clock to show these times: 6:15, 9:45, 2:30, 11:05, 4:20. Then I will set mine and you tell me what time it shows!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the clock master! Use your little clock to show me these times, and then I'll show you a time and you tell me what it is. You can do it!

slides.text: You can read so many times now! Notice the clocks in your house today and practice reading them.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read quarter-past, quarter-to, and at least 3 five-minute interval times on an analog clock?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you are amazing at telling time now! You can read so many different times on the clock, even the tricky ones! Look for clocks at home and practice reading them.

parent_notes: Time-telling builds on the child's skip-counting by 5s, which they have been practicing with bead chains. The connection between the 5-bead chain and the clock face is powerful — point it out! Quarter-hour language (quarter past, quarter to) uses fraction vocabulary the child will encounter more formally later. Keep a real analog clock in your learning space and ask the child to read it throughout the day. Digital clocks are fine for everyday use, but the analog clock develops number sense and spatial reasoning.

title: Geometric Shapes in Geography — Properties of Shapes
description: The child explores geometric shapes and their properties, connecting the sensorial work with geometric solids and the geometric cabinet to real-world geography. Triangles, rectangles, circles, and polygons are examined for their sides, angles, and occurrences in nature and architecture.
instructions:
1. Lay out the geometric cabinet insets: circle, triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon.
2. 'Let us look carefully at each shape. How many sides does the triangle have? How many corners?'
3. Count sides and vertices for each shape. Record on a chart.
4. 'Sides: circle=0, triangle=3, square=4, rectangle=4, pentagon=5, hexagon=6.'
5. 'Where do we see these shapes in the world?' Show photos: stop signs (octagon), windows (rectangle), wheels (circle), pyramids (triangle).
6. Go on a shape hunt around the house or yard.
7. Child draws each shape, labels it, and writes the number of sides.
materials_needed: Geometric cabinet insets or shape cut-outs
Photos of shapes in architecture and nature

slides.heading: Shapes and Their Properties
slides.subheading: Sides, Corners, and Where We See Them
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this first page! It tells us we're going to learn all about shapes, like circles and triangles, and how they have special parts called sides and corners. We'll even discover where we can see these shapes all around us in the big, wide world!

items: Geometric cabinet insets or cardboard shapes
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange shapes on a work mat. Prepare a chart with columns: Shape, Number of Sides, Number of Corners.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our fun shape adventure, we need a few things! See these shape cutouts? We'll use those to learn. We also have a big piece of paper for writing things down, some cool pictures of shapes in real places, and paper and colorful pencils for drawing. Can you help ask a grown-up to get these ready for us?

slides.text: 'We have explored these shapes with our hands in sensorial work. Today let us study them like scientists! How many sides does each shape have?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, remember how we've touched and played with these shapes before? Today, we're going to be like super scientists and look at them very closely to learn a special secret about them. Let's get ready to count how many sides each shape has, one by one!

slides.text: Trace each shape with your finger. Count sides together: 'Triangle: 1, 2, 3 sides. Square: 1, 2, 3, 4 sides.' Record on the chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's use our fingers to feel the outside edge of each shape. Feel that? That's a side! Let's count them together for the triangle: one, two, three sides! Now, let's do the square: one, two, three, four sides! We'll write down how many sides each shape has on our chart.

slides.text: 'Now count the corners — mathematicians call them vertices. A triangle has 3 vertices. A square has 4. Does a circle have any?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to count the pointy bits on the shapes, which are called corners, or 'vertices' by smart people. A triangle has three corners, and a square has four. What about a circle? Does it have any pointy corners at all? Let's see!

slides.text: Show photos: 'A stop sign is an octagon — 8 sides! Honeycombs are hexagons! The pyramids in Egypt have triangular faces! Shapes are everywhere in our world.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these pictures! That red shape with eight sides is a stop sign! And did you know that bee homes, called honeycombs, are made of hexagons with six sides? Even the giant pyramids in Egypt have triangle shapes! Shapes are hiding everywhere!

slides.prompt: Go on a shape hunt! Walk around your home and find at least one example of each shape: circle, triangle, rectangle, square. Draw each shape you find and label it with its name and number of sides.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for a shape hunt! Let's walk around our house or outside and be shape detectives. Can you find a circle, a square, a triangle, and a rectangle? When you find one, draw it on your paper, write its name, and tell me how many sides it has!

slides.text: Shapes have special properties — the number of sides and corners tells us their name. You are a geometry detective!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 5 shapes and state how many sides each has?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job being a shape detective today! You learned that shapes have special numbers of sides and corners that give them their names. You were amazing at finding shapes and counting their sides – you can name at least five shapes and tell me how many sides they have!

parent_notes: This lesson bridges sensorial and math by adding the language of geometry — sides, vertices, properties. In Montessori, the child has already handled these shapes extensively through the geometric cabinet; now we add the intellectual layer. The shape hunt makes abstract concepts concrete and relevant. You can extend this work by looking at shapes in maps (countries, states often have angular borders), architecture books, or nature (hexagonal honeycombs, spiral shells). This is also a natural connection to the geometric solids work from earlier in the year.

title: Read-Aloud: Stone Soup — A Classic Folk Tale
description: Reading the folk tale Stone Soup connects to the week's cooking theme. The story teaches cooperation, community, and the magic that happens when everyone contributes. Discussion focuses on how small contributions create something wonderful together.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This story is called Stone Soup. What do you think soup made from stones would taste like?'
2. Read the story expressively, pausing at key moments.
3. At the first addition: 'The traveler added carrots. What do you think will happen next?'
4. Continue reading, letting the child predict each villager's contribution.
5. After reading: 'Was it really the stone that made the soup delicious?'
6. 'What was the real ingredient?' Guide toward: sharing, community, cooperation.
7. Connect to the soup the child made today: 'You added many ingredients too! Which was your favorite?'
8. Optional: retell the story together.
materials_needed: Stone Soup by Marcia Brown (or Jon J Muth version)
A smooth stone to hold during the reading

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the book we get to read today. It's called "Stone Soup," and it's a story about making yummy soup!

items: A smooth stone for the child to hold
slides.setup_instructions: Settle into a cozy reading spot. Give the child the stone to hold during the story.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a few special things for our story time. We have our book, a smooth stone for you to hold, and some paper for drawing later. Let's get comfy and ready for our adventure!

slides.text: 'This is a very old story that people have told for hundreds of years, all around the world. It is about a traveler who was very hungry...'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the beginning of our story! It's about a traveler who was very, very hungry and found a village. Let's see what happens next in this old, special story!

slides.text: Read the story with expression. Pause when each villager adds an ingredient: 'Now what do you think will go in next?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story together. When we get to a part where someone adds something to the soup, I'll ask you what you think comes next. You can guess what yummy things they might put in!

slides.text: After the story: 'Was it really the stone that made the soup taste so good? What was the real secret ingredient?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we finished the story! What do you think? Was it really just the stone that made the soup so good? What do you think was the secret ingredient that made it taste amazing?

slides.prompt: Draw your own version of Stone Soup. What ingredients would YOU add? Draw the pot, the stone, and all the vegetables. Write or dictate the ingredients.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to draw our own Stone Soup! What yummy things would you put in the soup? Let's draw the big pot, the stone, and all the vegetables you imagine. You can tell me what you drew!

slides.text: When everyone shares a little, we create something wonderful together. That is the lesson of Stone Soup!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the main events of the story and explain the theme of sharing and cooperation?
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it neat how everyone in the story helped make something so delicious? When we all share and work together, we can make amazing things, just like in our Stone Soup story!

parent_notes: Stone Soup is a perfect companion to the cooking lesson. The folk tale exists in many cultures (French, Portuguese, Swedish, Brazilian), which you can explore if the child is interested. The deeper lesson — that community and generosity transform scarcity into abundance — resonates with Montessori values of cooperation and contributing to the group. Holding a real stone during the reading adds a tactile, concrete element. If your child enjoyed the story, they might want to act it out with stuffed animals or invite neighbors to a real stone soup dinner!

title: Weight Exploration with the Balance Scale
description: The child uses a balance scale to compare and order objects by weight. This sensorial experience of heaviness and lightness builds the foundation for formal measurement of mass and prepares for math work with standard units.
instructions:
1. Present the balance scale. 'This tool tells us which object is heavier and which is lighter.'
2. Place a wooden block on one side. 'See how it tips down? That side is heavier because the block is there.'
3. Place a cotton ball on the other side. 'Which is heavier?' The block side stays down.
4. Experiment: try to balance two objects of similar weight.
5. Introduce a set of 5-6 varied objects. Child predicts which is heaviest, then tests.
6. Child orders all objects from lightest to heaviest using the scale.
7. Introduce standard weights if available: 'This is 10 grams. Let us see how many cotton balls equal 10 grams.'
materials_needed: Set of varied objects (wooden block, cotton ball, stone, small apple, eraser, metal spoon)

slides.heading: The Balance Scale
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is our special tool for today, called a balance scale. It helps us learn about things that are heavy and things that are light. We're going to have so much fun exploring with it!

items: Varied objects: block, cotton ball, stone, apple, eraser, spoon
slides.setup_instructions: Set the balance scale on a stable, level surface. Arrange objects in a basket beside it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are all the fun things we get to use for our weight adventure! We have our balance scale that helps us see what's heavy. Then we have this cool block, a soft cotton ball, a smooth stone, a yummy apple, a little eraser, and a spoon. You can ask a grown-up to help you find these special things!

slides.text: 'This is a balance scale. When both sides are the same, it sits level. When one side is heavier, it tips down. Let us explore!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our balance scale, and it's like a magic seesaw for grown-ups and toys! When we put things on both sides, it tells us which one is heavier by tipping down. Let's see how it works!

slides.text: Place the wooden block on one side. 'It tips! The block is heavy. Now put the cotton ball on the other side. Which is heavier?' The block side stays down.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we put the block on one side, and see how it goes down? That means the block is heavy! Now, let's put the tiny cotton ball on the other side. Which side do you think is still heavier? Yep, the block side stays down because it's heavier than the cotton ball.

slides.text: 'Before we weigh each object, let us PREDICT. Hold the stone in one hand and the eraser in the other. Which do you THINK is heavier? Now let us test it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we put things on the scale, let's use our super-smart brains and our hands! Hold the stone in one hand and the eraser in the other. Which one feels heavier to you? Now, let's put them on the scale to see if you were right!

slides.text: 'Now order ALL the objects from lightest to heaviest. Compare two at a time on the scale. Record your results.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super fun challenge! We need to put all our toys in order, from the lightest one to the heaviest one. We'll put two toys on the scale at a time to see which is lighter, and then we'll line them all up. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Choose 5 objects from around the room. Predict which is heaviest, then test each pair on the balance scale. Order them from lightest to heaviest. Draw and label your results.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's go on a treasure hunt for some more things to weigh! Can you find five other things around the room? We'll guess which one is the heaviest, then we'll use our scale to check. After that, we'll line them all up from lightest to heaviest, just like a parade!

slides.text: Our hands can estimate weight, but the balance scale gives us an exact comparison. Scientists use scales to measure precisely!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use the balance scale to compare and order at least 4 objects by weight?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job using the balance scale today! You learned that our hands can feel weight, but the scale can tell us exactly which is heavier or lighter. Scientists use scales like this all the time to measure things very, very carefully!

parent_notes: The baric sense (sense of weight) is one of the sensorial refinements Montessori identified. Before introducing standard units (grams, ounces), children need extensive experience with relative weight — heavier, lighter, equal. The balance scale makes this visible and concrete. Encourage the child to hold objects in their hands first and predict before testing — this develops the baric sense and scientific thinking (hypothesis then experiment). If you have standard weights, introducing them connects to the math curriculum. Let the child explore freely after the lesson; they may spend a long time weighing everything in sight!

title: Compound Words — Reading and Spelling Practice
description: The child reads compound words in context, practices spelling them, and begins to use them in original sentences. This second lesson deepens understanding through reading passages and independent writing.
instructions:
1. Review yesterday's compound words. 'What two words make up sunflower?'
2. Read a short passage together that contains several compound words. Child identifies them.
3. 'Underline each compound word you find. Then draw a line between the two words inside it.'
4. Introduce new compound words: playground, grasshopper, waterfall, thunderstorm, notebook.
5. Child builds each with moveable alphabet, then writes them.
6. Child writes 3 sentences using compound words.
7. Share sentences aloud.
materials_needed: Prepared reading passage with compound words
Highlighter or colored pencil for underlining

slides.heading: Compound Words
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Compound Words." That means we're going to learn how to put two little words together to make a new, bigger word, like "sun" and "flower" make "sunflower"! We'll be reading and writing them today, just like a super smart reader!

slides.setup_instructions: Print or write a short passage (3-4 sentences) containing at least 5 compound words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some special things to help us learn today! We have a story to read, and a special crayon or marker to color with. Then, we have little letter pieces called a "moveable alphabet" to build words, and paper to write our own sentences. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'Yesterday we discovered compound words. Today let us find them in a real story! Read this passage and underline every compound word you spot.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about big words made of two little words yesterday? Well, today we get to be word detectives and find them in a story! We're going to read this story together, and when you see a word that's made of two smaller words, you'll underline it with your crayon.

slides.text: Child reads the passage. 'Draw a line between the two words hiding inside each compound word you found: play|ground, thunder|storm.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now that we found all those special words, let's look closer at them! See how "playground" is really "play" and "ground"? You're going to draw a line right in the middle of each word to show us the two words that are hiding inside. It's like a secret code!

slides.text: 'Here are some new compound words: playground, grasshopper, waterfall, thunderstorm, notebook. Build each one with the moveable alphabet.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are some super cool new compound words we're going to learn: "playground," "grasshopper," "waterfall," "thunderstorm," and "notebook." We'll use our letter pieces to build each one, putting the small words together to make the big word. It's like building with words!

slides.text: 'Now write three sentences using compound words. For example: The grasshopper jumped over the sunflower.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super sentence writer! We're going to write three sentences all by yourself. You can use any of the compound words we learned, like "The grasshopper jumped," or make up your own! Just try your best to put a compound word in each sentence.

slides.prompt: Write 3 sentences using at least one compound word in each. Underline the compound words. Try to use words from both yesterday and today!
slides.mascot_explanation: You get to be the author now! Write three sentences using some of our compound words. Remember to underline the compound word in each sentence you write. You're doing such a great job putting words together!

slides.text: You are becoming a compound word expert! Keep a list of new compound words you discover in your reading.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify compound words in text and use them correctly in original sentences?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are a compound word superstar! You found them in a story, you built them with letters, and you even wrote your own sentences using them! Isn't it amazing how two little words can make a whole new big word? Keep looking for them everywhere!

parent_notes: This second day solidifies compound word understanding through reading and writing application. The progression from building with the moveable alphabet to identifying in text to using in original writing mirrors the Montessori approach: concrete to abstract, receptive to expressive. If the child struggles with writing sentences, offer to take dictation — the important skill here is compound word recognition and oral composition. Keep a running compound word list on a poster; the child will delight in adding new discoveries.

title: Measurement — Weight with the Balance Scale
description: The child measures objects using standard gram weights on a balance scale, recording the weight of each object. This lesson connects the sensorial exploration of weight to precise mathematical measurement.
instructions:
1. 'Yesterday in sensorial work we compared objects — heavier and lighter. Today we will find out EXACTLY how heavy things are!'
2. Present standard gram weights: 1g, 5g, 10g, 20g, 50g. Child holds each.
3. Place an eraser on one side of the scale. Add gram weights to the other side until balanced.
4. 'The eraser weighs ___ grams!' Record on the chart.
5. Weigh 5-6 classroom objects. Child records each in a chart (object name, estimated weight, actual weight).
6. 'Which was the heaviest? The lightest? Were your estimates close?'
7. Challenge: 'Can you find something that weighs exactly 20 grams?'
materials_needed: Objects to weigh (eraser, crayon, small toy, apple, pencil, stone)

slides.heading: Measuring Weight
slides.subheading: Using Grams and the Balance Scale
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we're going to be super-duper measurers and find out *exactly* how heavy things are using special numbers called grams. We already know if things are heavy or light, but now we'll be like little scientists and find out the real weight!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the balance scale. Arrange gram weights in order. Prepare a chart: Object | Estimate | Actual Weight.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our tools ready for some fun measuring! We have a balance scale, which is like a seesaw for objects. We also have these little weights that tell us how heavy they are, like tiny building blocks of weight. And we'll need some things to weigh, like toys or blocks, and a paper to write down what we find. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'We know how to compare heavy and light. Now let us use these special weights to find out EXACTLY how heavy something is. This small weight is 1 gram.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We already know some things are heavier and some are lighter, right? Well, today we get to find out *exactly* how heavy they are! This little weight here is called 1 gram, and it's our starting point to figure out the weight of other things.

slides.text: 'Hold the 1 gram weight. Now hold the 10 gram weight. Feel the difference? 10 grams is ten times as heavy as 1 gram!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's feel these weights! Hold this tiny 1 gram weight in your hand. Now, hold this bigger 10 gram weight. Can you feel how much heavier the 10 gram one is? It's like 10 of the tiny weights all put together!

slides.text: 'Put the eraser on one side. Now add weights to the other side until the scale balances. Start with bigger weights and add smaller ones to get exact.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put this eraser on one side of our balance scale. We need to put weights on the other side, like a puzzle, until the scale is perfectly even, like a seesaw that's not tipping. We'll start with the bigger weights and then use the smaller ones to make it just right.

slides.text: 'Add up all the weights on the scale: 10 + 5 + 1 + 1 = 17 grams! The eraser weighs 17 grams. Write it on your chart.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, the scale is balanced! We need to count all the weights we used. If we have a 10 gram weight, and a 5 gram weight, and two 1 gram weights, that's 10 + 5 + 1 + 1, which makes 17 grams! So, our eraser weighs 17 grams, and we can write that down on our paper.

slides.prompt: Weigh 5 objects. For each one, first ESTIMATE the weight, then measure it. Record both numbers. Which estimate was closest?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the master measurer! Pick up about 5 different toys or objects. Before you weigh each one, guess how heavy you think it is – put that guess on your paper. Then, use the scale and weights to find out the real weight, and write that down too. Let's see which guess was the closest!

slides.text: Grams help us measure weight precisely. Scientists, chefs, and doctors all use grams!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use gram weights on a balance scale to determine an object's weight within 5 grams?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job measuring today! We learned that grams help us know *exactly* how heavy things are, and grown-ups like chefs and doctors use grams too! You were a fantastic measurer, especially when you were balancing the scale to find the exact weight!

parent_notes: This lesson beautifully connects sensorial exploration to mathematical precision — a hallmark of Montessori education. The estimation step is crucial: it develops number sense and the baric sense simultaneously. Children love the surprise when their estimate is close (or far off). Adding up the gram weights also reinforces addition skills. If you do not have official gram weights, you can use coins (a US nickel weighs exactly 5 grams) or small kitchen weights. Connect this to cooking: 'Remember when we measured ingredients? Grams tell us exactly how much!'

title: Simple Machines — Lever Experiments and Real-World Applications
description: Conducting lever experiments with different fulcrum positions and loads, then identifying levers in everyday objects like seesaws, scissors, and bottle openers.
instructions:
1. 'Have you ever used a seesaw? A seesaw is a type of simple machine called a LEVER!'
2. Build a lever: place a ruler across a triangular block (fulcrum).
3. Place a small heavy object (book) on one end. Press down on the other end to lift it.
4. 'The lever helped us lift something heavy with less effort! The triangle in the middle is called the FULCRUM.'
5. Experiment: move the fulcrum closer to the heavy object. 'Is it easier or harder to lift now?'
6. Move the fulcrum to the center. Compare. Move it far from the heavy object. Compare.
7. 'Where does the fulcrum need to be to make lifting easiest?'
8. Identify levers in everyday life: scissors, bottle opener, wheelbarrow, crowbar.
9. Draw and label a lever diagram.
materials_needed: Sturdy ruler or flat piece of wood
Triangular block or cylinder for fulcrum

slides.heading: Simple Machines
slides.subheading: Simple Machines — Lever Experiments and Real-World Applications
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that big title! It says "Simple Machines," and we're going to learn about special tools that help us do things, like lifting and moving! Today, we're going to play with something super cool called a "lever."

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the lever on a flat table: ruler balanced on the triangular block with the heavy object on one end.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our special tools ready for our fun experiment! We need a long, flat thing like a ruler, a bumpy triangle shape for our "turning point," and something a little heavy like a book. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things and set them up on a table?

slides.text: 'People have been inventing machines to make work easier for thousands of years. The simplest machines have no motors or electricity — they just use clever shapes! Today: the LEVER.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Did you know that people have been using clever tools to help them for a very, very long time? Some of the smartest tools don't even need batteries or plugs – they're called "simple machines," and today we're learning about one called a "lever"!

slides.text: 'A lever is a bar that rests on a turning point called a FULCRUM.' Show the setup. 'Push down on this end — watch the book LIFT on the other end!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this long stick on top of the triangle? That's our lever, and the bumpy triangle is called the "fulcrum" – it's like a special turning spot! Now, if you gently push down on one side, watch what happens to the book on the other side – it lifts right up!

slides.text: 'Now let us experiment! Move the fulcrum closer to the book. Push down. Is it easier or harder? Now move it far away. What happens?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for some super fun experimenting! Let's slide that triangle, the fulcrum, closer to the book. Now push down again – is it easier or harder to lift the book this time? Let's try moving the triangle far away from the book and see what happens!

slides.text: 'Closer fulcrum to the heavy thing = easier to lift! Levers are everywhere: scissors, seesaws, bottle openers, even your arm — your elbow is the fulcrum!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You found it! When the triangle, the fulcrum, is super close to the heavy thing, it's much, much easier to lift it up! Levers are like magic helpers that are all around us, like on a seesaw, or helping us open a bottle!

slides.prompt: Experiment with the lever: try lifting different objects. Move the fulcrum to different positions. Find 3 levers in your house. Draw and label a lever showing the fulcrum, effort, and load.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a scientist and an artist! Let's try lifting different toys with our lever and moving the triangle around to see what happens. Then, let's draw our own lever, showing the fulcrum, the part we push, and the part that lifts!

slides.text: A lever helps us lift heavy things with less effort. You discovered a rule: the closer the fulcrum is to the heavy object, the easier it is to lift!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what a lever and fulcrum are, and demonstrate how fulcrum position affects effort?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You learned that a lever is like a special helper bar, and the fulcrum is its turning spot. You discovered that moving the fulcrum closer to the heavy thing makes lifting it way easier – that's a super smart discovery!

parent_notes: Simple machines are a wonderful topic for Montessori children because they connect abstract physics concepts to concrete, hands-on experimentation. Archimedes said, 'Give me a lever long enough and I shall move the world!' The child is essentially conducting physics experiments — forming hypotheses and testing them. Let them play extensively with the lever setup; they may discover things you did not plan to teach. Scissors are a double lever (two levers joined at a pivot), which the child may notice. A wheelbarrow is a lever too — the wheel is the fulcrum, the handles are where you push, and the load is in the bucket.

title: Watercolor Painting — Vegetable Still Life
description: The child paints a still life of vegetables using watercolors, connecting to the week's cooking theme. The lesson focuses on color mixing, observation, and the technique of painting from light to dark.
instructions:
1. Arrange 2-3 vegetables (carrot, potato, celery) in a small group on a white cloth.
2. 'An artist who paints objects arranged on a table is painting a STILL LIFE. The objects sit still while you paint them!'
3. Demonstrate wet-on-wet technique: wet the paper first, then add color.
4. 'Look carefully at the carrot. What colors do you see? Orange, yes, but also some yellow and a bit of green at the top.'
5. Mix orange from red and yellow. Child experiments with mixing.
6. 'Paint the lightest colors first, then add darker details on top.'
7. Child paints their still life, observing the real vegetables closely.
8. Allow to dry. Label with title and date.
materials_needed: Two cups of water (one for rinsing, one for clean water)
White cloth or paper for background

slides.heading: Watercolor Still Life
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We are going to be artists today and paint some yummy vegetables. It's going to be so much fun, like making a colorful picture for our kitchen!

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange vegetables on the white cloth. Set up painting area with paper, paints, water cups, and towel.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our art supplies ready! We need our paint and brushes, special paper for painting, two cups of water (one for rinsing, one for mixing), some real vegetables like a carrot or potato, and a nice white cloth to put them on. Ask a grown-up to help you find everything so we can start!

slides.text: 'Artists often paint things they see right in front of them. When the objects sit still on a table, it is called a STILL LIFE. Famous artists like Cezanne painted beautiful still lifes of fruits and vegetables!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We are going to make a "still life" painting! That means we will look at some vegetables that are sitting very still, and then we'll paint them just as they are. It’s like playing a game where the vegetables have to stay super still for us!

slides.text: 'First, look very carefully. What SHAPES do you see? The carrot is long and thin like a triangle. The potato is like an oval. Sketch lightly with a pencil if you wish.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let’s look closely at our vegetables. What shapes do you see? The carrot is long and pointy, and the potato is round like a ball. You can even draw these shapes very lightly with a pencil if you want to remember them.

slides.text: 'Let us mix our colors! Red + yellow = orange for the carrot. What about the potato? It is not just brown — I see yellow and a little red and gray mixed together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to mix some colors! We can make orange for the carrot by mixing red and yellow paint together. For the potato, we can try mixing yellow, a little red, and maybe some gray to make its special color. It's like magic mixing!

slides.text: 'Paint the lightest colors first. Then add darker shadows on top while the first layer is still a little damp. This makes soft, beautiful edges.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we paint, we start with the light colors first, like yellow. Then, while that paint is still a little wet, we can add darker colors on top, like brown or green. This makes our painting look so soft and real!

slides.prompt: Paint your vegetable still life! Look back and forth between the real vegetables and your painting. Take your time — great art cannot be rushed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it’s your turn to be the artist! Look at your real vegetables and paint them on your paper. You can mix colors and paint light and dark parts, just like we learned. Take your time and make your beautiful vegetable picture!

slides.text: You painted from observation — looking carefully at real things and putting what you see onto paper. That is what artists do! Sign and date your painting.
slides.mastery_check: Did the child observe and attempt to represent the actual colors and shapes of the vegetables, mixing colors as needed?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You looked at the real vegetables and painted them, just like a real artist! That’s called painting from observation, and you are so good at it. Let's write your name and today's date on your amazing artwork!

parent_notes: Still life painting develops observational skills that transfer to science and language (descriptive writing). In Montessori, art is not about making things look perfect but about careful observation, experimentation with materials, and self-expression. Resist the urge to correct or improve the child's painting. If they paint a purple carrot, ask, 'Tell me about the colors you chose,' rather than saying, 'Carrots are orange.' Color mixing is a sensorial science experiment in itself. Connecting art to the cooking theme (painting the same vegetables they used in soup) enriches both experiences.

title: Laundry Skills — Sorting, Washing, and Folding
description: The child learns to sort laundry by color (whites, darks, colors), hand-wash a small item, and fold various types of clothing. This practical life lesson teaches responsibility, sequencing, and care of the environment.
instructions:
1. Gather a basket of mixed laundry (child's own clothes work best).
2. 'We need to sort our clothes before washing. Let us make three piles: whites, darks, and colors.'
3. Hold up each item: 'Is this light or dark? Which pile?' Child sorts independently.
4. Select one or two small items for hand washing.
5. Fill a basin with warm soapy water. Demonstrate: dip, rub gently, squeeze, rinse in clean water, wring out.
6. Hang items on a drying rack or clothesline with clothespins.
7. Take pre-dried clothes and demonstrate folding: shirts (fold in thirds), pants (fold in half lengthwise, then in half), socks (match and fold).
8. Child folds a small pile of their own clothes.
9. Put folded clothes away in the proper drawer.

slides.heading: Laundry Skills
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to learn how to be super helpers with our clothes! We'll learn how to make them clean and tidy, just like grown-ups do. Isn't that exciting?

slides.setup_instructions: Set up three labeled sorting areas. Prepare a basin with warm soapy water and a basin of clean rinse water.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our laundry adventure! We have a basket with clothes, and special baskets to put them in. We also have a tub for washing, some soap, and a special rack to help our clothes get dry. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Every day we wear clothes, and they get dirty. Taking care of our laundry is an important job! First, we SORT. White clothes go together, dark clothes together, and colored clothes together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See all these clothes? They all look a little mixed up, don't they? We need to help them find their friends! We'll make three special piles: one for the white clothes, one for the dark clothes, and one for all the colorful ones. This way, we know what to wash together.

slides.text: 'Hold up each piece. What color is it? Which pile does it belong in?' Let the child sort the entire basket independently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the sorter! Pick up one piece of clothing, and let's look at it together. Is it white, dark, or colorful? You get to decide which pile it belongs in. Let's sort all the clothes until every piece is in the right spot!

slides.text: 'Now let us wash this small item by hand. Dip it in soapy water. Rub gently — see the dirt coming out? Squeeze, but do not twist too hard. Rinse in clean water. Wring it out.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This little piece of clothing looks like it needs a bath! We'll dip it in the bubbly water and gently rub it to get the dirt out. Then we'll give it a nice rinse in clean water and give it a gentle squeeze. You're helping our clothes feel fresh and clean!

slides.text: 'Hang it up to dry with clothespins. Now let us practice folding! Watch: I fold the shirt in thirds — one side in, the other side over, then fold in half. Now you try!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to help our wet clothes dry! We use these little clips, called clothespins, to hang them up. After they're dry, we get to do the best part: folding! Watch how I fold this shirt, and then you can try folding some clothes too.

slides.prompt: Sort the remaining laundry. Then fold 5 items: 2 shirts, 2 pairs of pants, and match the socks. Put each item away in its proper place.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it’s time for you to be the laundry expert! Let's sort the rest of the clothes into their right piles. Then, we'll fold some shirts, pants, and even match up the socks! After we fold them, we'll put them away neatly in their drawers.

slides.text: You can sort, wash, and fold laundry! This is a real contribution to your family. You are taking care of yourself and your home.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort laundry by color, hand-wash a small item, and fold at least 3 types of clothing?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You learned how to sort, wash, and fold clothes all by yourself! That's a super important job, and you're helping our family so much. You're such a big helper!

parent_notes: Laundry is one of the most authentic practical life activities because it is genuinely useful and visible to the child as real work. Montessori emphasized that children should participate in the actual maintenance of their environment, not just practice on pretend tasks. Sorting develops classification skills (a cognitive operation), hand-washing develops fine motor strength and sequencing, and folding requires spatial reasoning. The child should put their own clean clothes away as the final step — this completes the cycle and builds ownership. Over time, this can become a regular household responsibility.

title: Contractions — Two Words Become One with an Apostrophe
description: The child learns that contractions are two words squeezed together with some letters removed and replaced by an apostrophe. Using word cards and hands-on manipulation, the child matches full forms to contractions.
instructions:
1. 'Yesterday we learned compound words — two words stuck together. Today is something different: CONTRACTIONS. Two words squeezed together with letters taken out!'
2. Write 'do not' on a card. 'When we talk fast, we say don't!' Write 'don't' next to it.
3. 'See this little mark? It is called an APOSTROPHE. It shows where the missing letters used to be.'
4. Practice with matching cards: I am/I'm, he is/he's, we are/we're, they will/they'll, can not/can't, is not/isn't, do not/don't, it is/it's.
5. Child matches pairs.
6. Say sentences with the full form; child responds with the contraction.
7. Child writes 5 contractions and their full forms in their journal.
materials_needed: Contraction matching cards (full form on one color, contraction on another)

slides.heading: Contractions
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Contractions," and that means we're going to learn how two words can give each other a big hug and squeeze together to make a new word! It's like they're playing a game to become one shorter word.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare matching cards: one set with full forms (do not, I am, etc.) and one set with contractions (don't, I'm, etc.) in a different color.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our game today! We have special cards with words on them, like a little puzzle. We also have a shiny apostrophe shape, which is a very important little mark. And we have a special book called a journal and a pencil for writing. Ask your grown-up to help you gather these things!

slides.text: 'Listen to how we talk: I am hungry. But when we speak quickly, we say I'm hungry! I'm is a CONTRACTION — we squeezed I and am together and dropped a letter.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Listen to how I say this: "I am hungry." Now, when we talk fast, it sounds like "I'm hungry!" See how "I am" squeezed together to make "I'm"? It's like they held hands so tight that one letter had to hop out!

slides.text: 'This little mark is called an apostrophe. It is like a placeholder that says: a letter used to be here! In don't, the apostrophe replaces the O in not.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this tiny little mark, it's called an apostrophe! It's like a special little helper that shows us where a letter used to be hiding. When we say "don't," that little apostrophe is standing where the 'o' from "not" used to be. It’s like a secret note!

slides.text: Lay out the full-form cards. 'Can you find the contraction that matches each one? Do not matches... don't! He is matches... he's!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be word detectives! We have these cards with longer words, and we need to find the shorter, squeezed-together word that matches. Can you find the card that goes with "do not"? That's right, it's "don't"! And "he is" goes with "he's"!

slides.text: 'Let us play a game! I will say the long form, and you say the contraction. We are = ? They will = ? Is not = ?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a fun talking game! I'll say the two words, and you tell me the squeezed-together word. If I say "we are," what do you say? You got it, "we're"! How about "is not"? Yes, "isn't"! You're doing so great!

slides.prompt: Match all the contraction cards. Then write 5 contractions in your journal. For each one, write the two words it comes from: don't = do + not.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let’s finish our word puzzle and then do some special writing! First, let's match all the word cards together. Then, in your journal, pick five of these squeezed-together words and write them down. For each one, show the two words that made it, like "don't" comes from "do" and "not."

slides.text: Contractions make our speech and writing sound natural. You will see them everywhere in the books you read!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match at least 6 contractions to their full forms and explain what the apostrophe represents?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job learning about contractions today! You learned how to squeeze words together and what that funny little apostrophe does. Now you'll see these special words in all the books you read, and you can even use them when you talk and write! High five!

parent_notes: Contractions are a natural part of spoken language, so children already use them — they just need to connect spoken forms to written ones. The apostrophe concept is important: it is not just a punctuation mark but a symbol showing that letters have been removed. This is different from the possessive apostrophe, which you may want to acknowledge if the child asks. Common confusion: its (possessive) vs. it's (it is) — but this distinction can wait until elementary. For now, focus on the most common contractions. Reading aloud from dialogue-heavy books helps children see contractions in context.

title: Geometry — Exploring 2D and 3D Shape Relationships
description: The child explores the relationship between 2D shapes and 3D solids, discovering that 3D shapes are made of 2D faces. By tracing the faces of geometric solids, the child connects flat shapes to solid forms.
instructions:
1. Review: place the geometric solids and the geometric cabinet insets on the work mat.
2. Pick up the cube. 'What shape is each face?' Trace one face on paper — it is a square!
3. 'A cube is made of 6 squares! Let us count: top, bottom, front, back, left, right.'
4. Trace the faces of other solids: cylinder (circles on the ends), triangular prism (triangles and rectangles).
5. 'Can you match each solid to the flat shapes that make it?'
6. Child traces faces of 3-4 solids and labels the 2D shapes.
7. Build a chart: 3D Shape | 2D Faces | How Many.
8. Extension: 'Can you figure out how many faces a pyramid has?'
materials_needed: Geometric solids (cube, cylinder, triangular prism, square pyramid, rectangular prism)

slides.heading: 2D and 3D Shapes
slides.mascot_explanation: Hello friend! Look at this fun title: "2D and 3D Shapes"! That means we're going to learn about flat shapes like squares and circles, and also shapes that are big and solid like a ball or a box. We'll discover a super cool secret about how they are connected!

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange geometric solids on the work mat with paper nearby for tracing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need! We have some cool blocks that are different shapes, and some paper and colorful pencils for drawing. We also have a big piece of paper to make a special chart. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things so we can start our shape adventure?

slides.text: 'We know our flat shapes — circle, triangle, square, rectangle. And we know our 3D solids. Today we will discover a secret: 3D shapes are MADE of flat shapes!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We know our flat shapes, right? Like a square or a circle! And we know our solid shapes, like a ball or a box. Today, we're going to learn that the big, solid shapes are actually made up of lots of flat shapes stuck together! Isn't that a neat secret?

slides.text: 'Hold the cube. Press one face onto the paper and trace around it. What shape did you make? A SQUARE! Every face of a cube is a square.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pick up the block that looks like a box. We call that a cube! Now, let's press one side of the cube onto our paper and trace all around it with a pencil. See? We made a flat shape, and it's a square! Every side of this cube is a square.

slides.text: 'How many square faces does the cube have? Let us count together: top, bottom, front, back, left side, right side — SIX squares make a cube!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This cube is made of squares, but how many? Let's count them together! There's one on the top, one on the bottom, one in the front, one in the back, one on this side, and one on that side. That makes six squares in total that build our cube!

slides.text: 'Now try the cylinder. Trace the bottom — it is a circle! What about the curved part? If we could unroll it, it would be a rectangle! A cylinder = 2 circles + 1 rectangle.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's try a different shape, like this one called a cylinder. If we trace the flat part on the bottom, what shape do we get? A circle! The curvy part is a little trickier, but if we imagine unrolling it, it would be a rectangle. So, this shape is made of two circles and one rectangle.

slides.prompt: Trace the faces of 3 different solids. Label each tracing with the name of the flat shape. Make a chart showing each 3D shape and how many faces it has.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a shape detective! Pick three different solid shapes and trace all their flat sides onto your paper. Then, write the name of the flat shape next to your drawing. After that, we'll make a chart to show all the cool shapes we found and how many flat sides each one has!

slides.text: Three-dimensional shapes are built from two-dimensional shapes! Architects and engineers think about shapes this way when they design buildings.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the 2D faces of at least 3 different 3D solids?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job finding the flat shapes that make up the solid shapes! It's like building with blocks, but with shapes! Remember how we saw that a cube is made of six squares? That's how builders and architects think about making real buildings!

parent_notes: This lesson creates a powerful bridge between the sensorial work (geometric solids and geometric cabinet) and abstract geometry. Tracing the faces makes the relationship physical and visible. The concept that 3D shapes are composed of 2D surfaces is foundational for later geometry. If your child is interested, you can unfold a cereal box to show how a rectangular prism is made of rectangles. Nets (unfolded 3D shapes) are a wonderful extension. The vocabulary of faces, edges, and vertices is being introduced naturally through this hands-on exploration.

title: Soups of the World — Food Traditions Across Cultures
description: The child explores how different cultures around the world make soup, connecting the week's cooking theme to cultural studies. From Japanese miso to Mexican tortilla soup to West African peanut soup, children discover that every culture has its own special soup tradition.
instructions:
1. 'We made vegetable soup this week! Did you know that people in EVERY culture around the world make soup?'
2. Show photos and discuss soups from different regions:
   - Japan: miso soup (with tofu and seaweed)
   - Mexico: tortilla soup (with tomatoes, peppers, tortilla strips)
   - Italy: minestrone (vegetables, beans, pasta)
   - West Africa: peanut soup (with peanut butter, tomatoes, sweet potato)
   - France: French onion soup (with onions, bread, cheese)
   - China: wonton soup (with dumplings)
3. Find each country on the globe or world map.
4. 'What do all these soups have in common? They all use water and local ingredients!'
5. Child draws their favorite soup from another culture.
6. Optional: taste a new soup variety at lunch.
materials_needed: Photos of soups from different cultures

slides.heading: Soups of the World
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Soups of the World," and it's all about how people in different places make yummy soup! We're going to learn about all sorts of new kinds of soup today.

items: Photos of soups from various cultures
slides.setup_instructions: Print photos of 6 different soups from around the world. Place the globe nearby for locating countries.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our soup adventure! We have a big map to find countries, some pretty pictures of soup, and paper and crayons for drawing. Ask your grown-up to help you find these things so we can get started!

slides.text: 'We made vegetable soup with carrots, celery, and potatoes — ingredients that grow where we live. People all over the world make soup, but they use the special ingredients that grow in THEIR part of the world!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We made yummy vegetable soup this week, right? Well, guess what? People everywhere in the whole world make soup too, but they use the yummy foods that grow near them!

slides.text: 'In Japan, people make miso soup with soybean paste, tofu, and seaweed. Let us find Japan on the globe!' Locate Japan. 'In Mexico, tortilla soup uses tomatoes and chilies.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's find Japan on our map! They make a soup called miso soup with soft little cubes and some yummy seaweed. Then, we'll look for Mexico, where they make soup with tomatoes and crunchy tortilla strips!

slides.text: 'In West Africa, peanut soup is made with peanut butter and sweet potatoes. In Italy, minestrone has beans and pasta. In France, they make soup from just onions, bread, and cheese!'
slides.mascot_explanation: And guess what else? In Africa, they make soup with peanut butter! Italy has a soup with beans and noodles, and France even makes soup with onions and bread and cheese! So many yummy kinds!

slides.text: 'What do ALL these soups have in common? Water! And local ingredients — what grows nearby. Soup is a way every culture feeds families with love.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't that cool? All these different soups have something special the same: they all use water, and they all use the yummy foods that grow close by. It's like a hug in a bowl from every country!

slides.prompt: Choose your favorite soup from another culture. Draw a bowl of that soup with all its ingredients. Label the country it comes from. Find that country on the globe!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a soup artist! Pick your favorite soup we talked about, draw a big bowl of it, and show me all the tasty things inside. Then, we'll find its country on the map together!

slides.text: Every culture has comfort food, and soup is one of the oldest and most universal foods in human history. People have been making soup for thousands of years!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 soups from different cultures and locate those countries on a globe?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about all those different soups! You can name so many kinds, and you even found their countries on the map. Soup is a super old and special food that families everywhere love!

parent_notes: This cultural lesson connects beautifully to the week's cooking theme. In Montessori, cultural studies help children develop respect and appreciation for human diversity while recognizing our shared humanity. The universal nature of soup — every culture has some version — illustrates both diversity (different ingredients and flavors) and unity (the basic concept of warming, nourishing food). If possible, try making one of these soups later in the week. Miso soup is very simple: miso paste dissolved in hot water with cubed tofu. This kind of cross-cultural tasting experience is deeply enriching.

title: Read-Aloud: Rosie Revere, Engineer by Andrea Beaty
description: This read-aloud introduces the theme of simple machines and engineering through the story of a girl who loves to build inventions. The story emphasizes persistence, creativity, and learning from failure — connecting to the week's science work on levers.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Rosie Revere. She is an engineer — someone who designs and builds things!'
2. Read the story with expression, pausing to examine the illustrations of Rosie's inventions.
3. At the 'failure' moment: 'How do you think Rosie feels when her invention does not work?'
4. Continue to the key message: 'The only true failure is when you stop trying!'
5. 'What did Great-Great-Aunt Rose say? Life might have its failures, but this is not it. The only true failure can come if you quit.'
6. Connect to the week: 'We learned about levers this week. Rosie uses simple machines in her inventions!'
7. Discuss: 'What would YOU like to invent? What problem would it solve?'
8. Child draws an invention design.
materials_needed: Rosie Revere, Engineer by Andrea Beaty

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! We are going to read a super fun story today about a girl named Rosie. She loves to make amazing things, just like you might love to build with blocks!

items: Rosie Revere, Engineer by Andrea Beaty
slides.setup_instructions: Settle into a cozy reading spot. Have drawing materials ready for the invention activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story and a cool activity, we need a few things. We need the book, Rosie Revere, Engineer, and then some paper and crayons or pencils so we can draw!

slides.text: 'Rosie is a quiet girl with a big dream — she loves to build things! But she is afraid to show anyone her inventions. Let us find out what happens...'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is Rosie! She's a smart girl who loves to build, but she feels a little shy about her creations. Let's read and see what exciting things she makes!

slides.text: Read with expression. Pause at the illustrations: 'Look at all the things Rosie built! What materials did she use? Can you see any simple machines?'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we read, we will look really closely at the pictures. We can see all the cool things Rosie built and think about what they are made of and how they work!

slides.text: After reading: 'What was the most important lesson Rosie learned? That failing is not the end — it is just the first step! Every great inventor fails many times.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Rosie learns something very important in our story. Even if her inventions don't work perfectly the first time, she learns that it's okay to try again!

slides.prompt: Design your own invention! What problem would it solve? Draw your invention and label its parts. What materials would you need to build it?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's YOUR turn to be an inventor! Think of something that could help people or make something easier, and draw a picture of your amazing invention. What problem will it fix?

slides.text: Like Rosie, real engineers try, fail, learn, and try again. That is how all great inventions are born. Never be afraid to try!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain Rosie's key lesson and describe an invention idea with some detail?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job listening and drawing! Just like Rosie, you learned that trying new things and not giving up is how we make wonderful inventions. Keep dreaming big!

parent_notes: Rosie Revere, Engineer connects STEM concepts to social-emotional learning. The growth mindset message — failure is not the end but the beginning of learning — aligns with Montessori philosophy, where errors are seen as learning opportunities, not things to be ashamed of. After reading, you might explore real inventors who failed many times: Thomas Edison, the Wright brothers. The invention drawing activity encourages creative thinking and design. If the child is inspired, provide recycled materials (boxes, tubes, tape) to actually build a prototype!

title: Thermic Bottles — Sensing Temperature Differences
description: The child uses thermic bottles (or household containers) filled with water at different temperatures to refine the thermic sense. Matching pairs of equal temperature and grading from coldest to warmest develops sensory discrimination.
instructions:
1. Prepare 4-6 pairs of small identical bottles filled with water at different temperatures: cold (refrigerator), cool (room temp), warm (from the tap), hot (warm but safe to touch).
2. 'We use our skin to feel temperature. Today we will train our thermic sense — our ability to feel hot and cold.'
3. Present two bottles: one cold, one warm. Child holds one in each hand. 'Which is warmer?'
4. Introduce all bottles mixed up. Child finds matching pairs by feeling.
5. Grade unpaired bottles from coldest to warmest.
6. Blindfold challenge: can the child identify cold, cool, warm, and hot with eyes closed?
7. Vocabulary: 'cold, cool, lukewarm, warm, hot.'
materials_needed: 8 small identical bottles or metal containers

slides.heading: Thermic Bottles
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, friends! Today we're going to play a game all about feeling! We'll use special bottles to learn all about how things feel hot or cold. It's going to be so much fun to explore with our hands!

items: 8 identical bottles filled with water at 4 temperatures (pairs)
slides.setup_instructions: Fill bottles in advance. Mark the bottoms with matching colors for control of error. Use safe temperatures only — nothing too hot to hold.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special bottles! We have some that are cold, some cool, some warm, and some just right so we can feel the difference. We also have a soft blindfold so we can try feeling with our eyes closed, and some cards with words to help us. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things so we can play!

slides.text: 'Your skin can feel temperature — hot, cold, and everything in between. Today we are going to see how sensitive your thermic sense is!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Your skin is like a super-duper sensor! It can tell us if something is warm like a cozy blanket or cold like ice cream. Today, we're going to practice using our skin to feel these special temperatures. It's like training our "thermic sense" to be extra good at noticing!

slides.text: 'Hold this bottle in one hand and this one in the other. Which is warmer? Which is cooler? Your skin is telling you!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's try something super cool! Hold one bottle in this hand and one in that hand. Close your eyes for a second and just feel. Can you tell which one feels warmer and which one feels cooler? Your skin is so smart, it's telling you all about it!

slides.text: 'Now I have mixed up all the bottles. Your job: find the MATCHING pairs! Two bottles that feel the same temperature belong together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, look! All the bottles are mixed up, like a puzzle! Your job is to be a super detective and find the bottles that feel exactly the same. Find two bottles that are both cold, then find two that are both warm. They are matching pairs!

slides.text: 'Now put them in order: coldest to warmest. Check by looking at the colored marks on the bottom.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We found the pairs! Now let's put them in a line, like a little temperature rainbow. We start with the *coldest* bottle, then the next coldest, and go all the way up to the *warmest* one. You can peek at the little colored dots on the bottom to help you remember the order.

slides.prompt: Close your eyes or wear the blindfold. I will hand you bottles one at a time. Tell me: is it cold, cool, warm, or hot? Then find its matching partner!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a super special game! Put on the blindfold, or just close your eyes really tight. I'll give you a bottle, and you tell me if it feels cold, cool, warm, or hot. Then, you have to find its matching friend without peeking! You can do it!

slides.text: Your thermic sense is amazing! You can feel tiny differences in temperature. Scientists use thermometers to measure exactly, but your skin gives you instant information.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match at least 3 pairs of thermic bottles and grade them from coldest to warmest?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job feeling all the different temperatures! Your skin is like a special thermometer, telling you if things are hot or cold. You were so good at finding the matching pairs and putting them in order, that was super impressive!

parent_notes: The thermic sense is one of the less commonly explored senses in Montessori, but it is a real and important sensory channel. This activity must be done with safe temperatures — nothing hot enough to burn. Refrigerator-cold, room temperature, comfortably warm tap water, and warm (not hot) water are sufficient. The child's ability to discriminate fine temperature differences improves dramatically with practice. Metal containers transfer heat to the hand faster than plastic and give a more pronounced sensation. If you do not have matching bottles, use identical mugs or small jars.

title: Reading Chapter Books — Guided Independent Reading
description: The child selects and reads from a beginning chapter book, practicing sustained reading for 15+ minutes. This lesson establishes independent reading habits and introduces strategies for tackling longer texts with chapters and fewer illustrations.
instructions:
1. Present 2-3 beginning chapter books appropriate for the child's level (Frog and Toad, Henry and Mudge, Mercy Watson, Owl at Home).
2. 'You are a strong enough reader now to read CHAPTER BOOKS! These are longer stories divided into chapters — like sections.'
3. Examine the book together: table of contents, chapter titles, fewer pictures.
4. 'When you come to a word you do not know, here are your strategies: sound it out, look at the picture, read the rest of the sentence, or ask me.'
5. Child reads Chapter 1 independently or with minimal support.
6. After reading: 'Tell me what happened in this chapter. Who are the characters? What was the problem?'
7. Discuss: 'Would you like to keep reading this book? What do you think will happen next?'
8. Establish a daily independent reading time (15-20 minutes).
materials_needed: 2-3 beginning chapter books at the child's reading level

slides.heading: Chapter Books
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Chapter Books" and "Independent Reading Adventures." That means you are a super reader now, ready for bigger stories all by yourself! We are going on an adventure with these books.

items: Beginning chapter books (Frog and Toad, Henry and Mudge, etc.)
