slides.setup_instructions: Set up a cozy, quiet reading area. Present book choices attractively.
slides.mascot_explanation: We have some special books here for you! See these chapter books? They have a bookmark to help us remember our spot and a reading log to write down all the amazing books you read. Let's find a comfy spot to start our reading adventure.

slides.text: 'You have been reading so well! Now you are ready for chapter books — longer stories divided into parts called chapters. Each chapter is like a mini-story inside the bigger story.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a great reader! Now you get to try chapter books, which are longer stories. Think of them like a big story made up of smaller parts, and each part is called a chapter.

slides.text: 'Look at the table of contents — it tells you the name of each chapter. Flip through the book. See how there are fewer pictures? Your imagination creates the pictures now!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look inside the book! This part at the beginning tells us all the chapter names, like a map for our story. And see, there are fewer pictures now, so your amazing imagination can fill in the rest!

slides.text: 'Choose the book that interests you most. When you find a tricky word, remember your strategies: sound it out, use the context, check the picture, or ask me.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to pick your adventure! Which book looks the most exciting to you? If you see a word that's a bit tricky, remember you can sound it out, look at the pictures, read the sentence again, or just ask me for help.

slides.text: 'Read Chapter 1 quietly. I will be right here if you need help. Use your bookmark to mark your place when you stop.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's start reading Chapter 1 of your book. I'll be right here if you need me, but try your best to read it all by yourself. When you need to stop, use your bookmark to save your place.

slides.prompt: Read Chapter 1 of your chosen book. When you finish, tell me: What happened? Who are the main characters? Did anything surprise you? Would you like to read more?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read a whole chapter! Now, tell me, what was the story about in that chapter? Who were the characters, and what did they do? Do you want to keep reading this book?

slides.text: You just read a whole chapter! From now on, let us set aside 15-20 minutes every day just for reading your chapter book. Mark your page with the bookmark!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a beginning chapter book chapter with 90%+ accuracy and retell the main events?
slides.mascot_explanation: That was amazing! You read a whole chapter all by yourself! From now on, we'll read chapter books for 15 to 20 minutes every day. Just remember to use your bookmark to save your special spot!

parent_notes: The transition from picture books to chapter books is a major milestone. Some children are eager; others find the lack of illustrations daunting. Choose books with some illustrations and short chapters (Frog and Toad chapters are only 5-6 pages). The key is to let the child CHOOSE the book — intrinsic motivation is essential for developing a reading habit. Do not force a book the child dislikes. Establishing a daily independent reading time is one of the most impactful things you can do. Model reading yourself — when the child reads, you read too. This silent companionship is powerful.

title: Geometry — Symmetry and Mirror Lines
description: The child explores symmetry by folding shapes in half to discover mirror lines, then creates symmetrical designs. This lesson develops spatial reasoning and connects to art and nature.
instructions:
1. 'Some shapes look exactly the same on both sides. We call that SYMMETRY!'
2. Cut out a paper heart. Fold it in half. 'See? Both sides match perfectly! The fold line is called the LINE OF SYMMETRY.'
3. Test other shapes: fold a square (4 lines of symmetry), circle (infinite), rectangle (2), triangle (1 or 3).
4. 'Some things in nature are symmetrical too: butterflies, leaves, faces!'
5. Show a photo of a butterfly. 'If we drew a line down the middle, both sides would match!'
6. Symmetry art: fold a paper in half, paint on one side only, press together. Open to reveal the symmetrical design.
7. Child tests 5 objects or shapes for symmetry using the fold test.
materials_needed: Pre-cut shapes (heart, square, circle, rectangle, triangle)
Photos of symmetrical objects in nature

slides.heading: Symmetry
slides.subheading: Mirror Lines in Shapes and Nature
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that word! It says "Symmetry." That means things that are the same on both sides, like a mirror picture! We are going to learn all about it today.

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut several shapes from paper. Set up a paint area for symmetry art. Have a small mirror available for testing symmetry.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special things ready for our fun symmetry game! We have some pretty paper shapes and some colorful paint. We'll also use scissors to help us, and maybe a little mirror to see our own matching sides! Ask a grown-up to help you find all these neat things.

slides.text: 'Look at this heart. If I fold it right down the middle... both sides match EXACTLY! This is called SYMMETRY. The fold is the line of symmetry.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this pretty heart? We are going to fold it right down the middle, like this! Ta-da! Look, both sides match perfectly, like magic! That special fold line is called the line of symmetry.

slides.text: 'Does the square have symmetry?' Fold in half vertically — yes! Fold horizontally — yes! Fold diagonally — yes! 'A square has FOUR lines of symmetry!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's look at this square! If we fold it this way, the sides match! And if we fold it this way, they match too! This square is super special because it has four lines of symmetry!

slides.text: 'Nature loves symmetry! Butterflies, starfish, snowflakes, leaves — they all have matching sides. Your face is almost symmetrical too! Hold the mirror on your nose and look.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? Lots of things in nature are symmetrical too, like beautiful butterflies and pretty leaves! Even your face is almost the same on both sides. Let's hold a mirror up to your face to see your matching sides!

slides.text: 'Let us make symmetry art! Fold your paper in half. Open it. Paint a design on ONE side only. Now fold it closed and press. Open it up — surprise!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make some amazing art that's symmetrical! First, we'll fold our paper in half, then we'll paint a fun picture on just one side. Then we'll fold it closed and squish, and when we open it, we'll see a perfect matching picture!

slides.prompt: Create a symmetry painting. Then test 5 shapes or objects: fold them or use the mirror to check — are they symmetrical? Draw the line of symmetry on each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a symmetry detective! Let's make a colorful symmetrical painting, and then you can test five different shapes or things to see if they have matching sides. You can fold them or use the mirror to find the special line of symmetry!

slides.text: Symmetry is one of the most beautiful patterns in mathematics and nature. Keep looking for it everywhere you go!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify lines of symmetry in at least 4 shapes and create a symmetrical design?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job finding symmetry today! You made a beautiful symmetrical painting and found the matching sides on so many shapes. Keep your eyes open, because symmetry is hiding everywhere you look!

parent_notes: Symmetry connects mathematics to art and nature in a way children find deeply satisfying. The fold test is a concrete, self-correcting way to check symmetry — very Montessori. The mirror tool is particularly powerful: placing a mirror on the line of symmetry shows how one half reflects to create the whole. Symmetry painting (fold-and-press) produces beautiful results that build confidence and delight. If the child becomes fascinated, explore bilateral symmetry (butterflies, faces) vs. radial symmetry (starfish, snowflakes). This work also connects to the botany and zoology curriculum.

title: Simple Machines — The Inclined Plane (Ramp)
description: The child experiments with ramps to discover how an inclined plane makes it easier to move objects upward. By changing the ramp angle and testing with different objects, the child learns that a longer, gentler slope requires less effort.
instructions:
1. 'Last time we learned about the lever. Today: the INCLINED PLANE — you probably call it a ramp!'
2. Set up a ramp using a board propped on books.
3. 'Try lifting this toy car straight up to the top of the books. Now try rolling it up the ramp. Which was easier?'
4. 'The ramp spreads the work over a longer distance, so it feels easier!'
5. Experiment: make the ramp steeper (more books). 'Is it harder or easier?' Make it gentler (fewer books or longer board). Compare.
6. Roll different objects: heavy toy, ball, cylinder. 'Which rolls easiest?'
7. Find ramps in real life: wheelchair ramps, slides, loading ramps, roads up hills.
8. Draw and label an inclined plane.
materials_needed: Various objects to test (ball, cylinder, heavy toy)

slides.heading: Simple Machines
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! We're learning about something super cool called "Simple Machines," and today we're going to explore a special one called the Inclined Plane. That's just a fancy name for a ramp!

slides.setup_instructions: Prop the board on a stack of 3-4 books to create a ramp. Have extra books to change the angle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special ramp-building stuff ready! We have a flat board that will be our ramp, and some books to make it go up high. We also have a fun toy car and some other things to try, plus paper and a pencil for drawing. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Our second simple machine is the INCLINED PLANE. That is the science name for a ramp! Ramps help us move things up without lifting straight up.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, a ramp is like a secret helper for going up! Instead of lifting something straight up, which can be hard work, we can use a ramp to slide or roll it up. It's like magic for moving things!

slides.text: 'Try lifting this toy car straight up to the top of the books. Hard, right? Now place it at the bottom of the ramp and push it up. Was that easier?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try something fun! Can you pick up your toy car and try to lift it all the way to the top of the books? Whew, that's a little tricky, right? Now, let's put the car at the bottom of our ramp and gently push it up. See? That felt much easier!

slides.text: 'Now let us experiment! Add more books to make the ramp steeper. Is it harder or easier to push the car up? Take books away to make it gentler. What happens?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for some super fun experimenting! Let's add more books to make our ramp super steep, like a slippery slide. Push the car up now – is it harder or easier? Then, let's take some books away so the ramp is long and gentle. What happens when you push the car up this time?

slides.text: 'A gentler ramp is easier but longer. A steep ramp is harder but shorter. That is the trade-off! Where do you see ramps in real life? Wheelchair ramps, playground slides, driveways!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's like a little puzzle! When the ramp is long and not too steep, it's easier to push things up, but you have to go a little further. If the ramp is short and steep, it's harder, but you get there faster! Think about a slide at the park – that’s a ramp too!

slides.prompt: Build ramps at 3 different angles. Test each with the toy car. Which angle is easiest? Hardest? Draw your experiment and write what you discovered.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, super scientist! Now it’s your turn to build and test! Let's make three different ramps using the books, not too steep, a little steep, and very steep. We'll roll the toy car up each one and see which one is the easiest and which is the hardest. Then, let’s draw a picture of what we did and write down what we learned!

slides.text: An inclined plane lets us go up using less force, but over a longer distance. That is why mountain roads zigzag — it is a long, gentle ramp!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how a ramp makes lifting easier and demonstrate how angle affects difficulty?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job being a ramp builder and scientist! We learned that ramps, or inclined planes, make it easier to move things up by spreading the work out. Remember how the gentle ramp felt easier than the steep one? That's our big discovery today!

parent_notes: The inclined plane is everywhere once you start looking: ramps, slides, escalators, even a knife blade (a wedge is two inclined planes together). The key physics concept — a longer, gentler slope requires less force but more distance — is something children intuit through experimentation. Let them test extensively. Some children will want to build elaborate ramp systems; encourage this! You can connect to the geography curriculum: 'Why do mountain roads have switchbacks instead of going straight up?' The answer is the same principle: a longer, gentler path requires less effort.

title: Music — Rhythmic Patterns and Body Percussion
description: The child creates and performs rhythmic patterns using body percussion (clapping, stomping, snapping, patting knees). This lesson develops the sense of rhythm, pattern recognition, and prepares for music reading.
instructions:
1. 'Music is made of rhythm — patterns of sound! Your body is an instrument. Let us explore!'
2. Demonstrate body percussion sounds: clap, stomp, pat knees, snap fingers.
3. Create a simple pattern: clap-clap-stomp. Repeat 4 times. 'That is a rhythm pattern!'
4. Child echoes your patterns (call and response).
5. Make patterns more complex: clap-stomp-pat-pat-clap.
6. 'Now YOU create a pattern! Teach it to me!'
7. Introduce simple rhythm notation: big circles = clap, squares = stomp, small circles = pat.
8. Child writes a 4-beat pattern using symbols, then performs it.
9. Layer patterns: parent keeps a steady clap while child adds a different pattern on top.
materials_needed: No special materials needed — just your body!

slides.heading: Rhythm Patterns
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Rhythm Patterns" and "Body Percussion." That means we're going to make cool sound patterns using just our bodies! Aren't you excited to play with sounds?

items: Paper and colored markers for notation
slides.setup_instructions: Clear space for movement. No setup needed — your body is the instrument!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we get to play with sounds! We don't need any special toys, just our amazing bodies! If you have some paper and colorful markers, you can draw our music, and maybe a drum or a fun shaker if you want. Let's get ready to wiggle and make some noise!

slides.text: 'Your body can make so many different sounds! CLAP your hands — that is one sound. STOMP your foot — another! PAT your knees — another! SNAP your fingers — another!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our bodies are like musical instruments! Let's try making some sounds together. Can you clap your hands really loud? Now, stomp your feet on the floor! Let's pat our knees too, and if you can, try to snap your fingers. So many fun sounds!

slides.text: 'A RHYTHM is a pattern of sounds. Listen and copy me: CLAP-CLAP-STOMP!' Repeat several times until the child joins in confidently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to play a copycat game with sounds! A rhythm is like a special beat, a pattern of sounds. Listen carefully: CLAP-CLAP-STOMP! Can you do that with me? Let's do it again and again until you're a super sound copier!

slides.text: 'Let us make it harder: CLAP-STOMP-PAT-PAT-CLAP! Can you echo me?' Practice several patterns of increasing complexity.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to make our sound patterns a little trickier now! Listen to this: CLAP-STOMP-PAT-PAT-CLAP! Can you copy that whole pattern? It's like a fun puzzle for your ears and your body! Let's try a few more tricky ones together.

slides.text: 'We can WRITE rhythm too! A big circle means clap, a square means stomp, a small circle means pat. Let me write our pattern: O O □ — that says clap-clap-stomp!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? We can even draw our sound patterns so we don't forget them! A big circle means clap, a square means stomp, and a little circle means pat. So, if I draw O O □, that means CLAP-CLAP-STOMP! Isn't that neat?

slides.prompt: Create your OWN rhythm pattern using at least 4 beats. Write it using our symbols. Practice it until it is smooth, then teach it to me!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the music maker! Can you think of your very own rhythm pattern with at least four sounds? Use our special drawings – circles for claps, squares for stomps, and little circles for pats – to write it down. Then, practice your pattern until it sounds super cool, and teach it to me!

slides.text: You are a composer! You created rhythm, wrote it down, and performed it. Real musicians do exactly the same thing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create, notate, and perform a rhythmic pattern of at least 4 beats?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are a real composer, just like grown-ups who make music! You made up a rhythm, you drew it so we could see it, and you played it perfectly. That's exactly what musicians do! You should be so proud of yourself!

parent_notes: Body percussion is a powerful and accessible way to develop musicality. No instruments are needed — just a willing body! The progression from echoing (receptive) to creating (expressive) mirrors language development. The simple notation system introduces the concept of written music without the complexity of standard notation. If the child enjoys this, explore more body percussion on YouTube (search 'body percussion for kids'). This work connects to math (patterns, sequencing) and language (rhythm in speech and poetry). In many cultures, body percussion and vocal rhythm are central to musical tradition.

title: Muffin Baking — Following a Recipe with Measuring
description: The child follows a written recipe to bake muffins, practicing measuring with cups and spoons, mixing, pouring, and using an oven with supervision. This project integrates reading (the recipe), math (measuring), and practical life skills.
instructions:
1. Read the recipe together: simple banana muffins or blueberry muffins.
2. Gather all ingredients and tools.
3. Child reads each step aloud.
4. Demonstrate measuring: level a measuring cup with flour, pack brown sugar, pour milk.
5. Child measures each ingredient independently.
6. Mix dry ingredients in one bowl, wet in another. Combine.
7. Child fills muffin cups 2/3 full using a spoon or small scoop.
8. Adult places in oven. Child sets the timer.
9. While baking: wash all dishes and wipe counters.
10. Remove from oven (adult). Cool on rack. Child serves muffins to family.
11. Review: 'What did we measure? What fractions did we use? 1/2 cup, 1/3 cup?'
materials_needed: Muffin recipe (printed or in a cookbook)
Measuring cups (1 cup, 1/2 cup, 1/3 cup, 1/4 cup)
All recipe ingredients (flour, sugar, egg, milk, butter, baking powder, fruit)

slides.heading: Baking Muffins
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we're going to be super chefs and bake yummy muffins! We get to follow a special recipe, just like a real baker. It's going to be so much fun making something delicious together.

slides.setup_instructions: Print the recipe large enough for the child to read. Lay out all ingredients and tools before beginning.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these cool tools and yummy things we need for our baking adventure! We have a recipe to read, special cups and spoons for measuring, big bowls for mixing, and a tin to make our muffins in. Ask your grown-up to help you find everything so we can get started!

slides.text: 'Today we are BAKING! Baking is like a science experiment — we have to measure exactly and follow the steps in order. Let us read our recipe first.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to be bakers today, and bakers follow a special recipe! This recipe tells us exactly what to do, like a treasure map for baking. Let's read it together so we know all the fun steps we'll take.

slides.text: 'Read step one aloud. What does it say? Measure 1 and 1/2 cups of flour. That is one full cup plus one half cup. Level it off with a knife — we need EXACTLY the right amount.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our recipe says we need flour! We need one whole cup and then one more half of a cup. See this flat edge? We use it to make the flour flat and even, so we have just the right amount.

slides.text: 'Mix the dry ingredients in this bowl. Mix the wet ingredients in the other bowl. Now pour the wet into the dry and stir gently — do NOT overmix! Just until combined.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to mix things! We'll put the dry stuff in one bowl and the wet stuff in another. Then, we'll pour the wet into the dry and stir it up just a little bit. We want it all mixed, but not too much!

slides.text: 'Fill each muffin cup about 2/3 full — not to the top or they will overflow! I will put them in the oven. You set the timer for 20 minutes.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Almost ready! We need to fill these little muffin cups, but not all the way to the top. Just about two-thirds full is perfect! Then, I'll help put them in the warm oven, and you get to be the timer master and count the minutes until they're done.

slides.prompt: While the muffins bake, wash all the dishes, wipe the counter, and put away the ingredients. Then set the table with plates and napkins for muffin time!
slides.mascot_explanation: While our muffins are baking, we have important jobs to do! Let's wash all our bowls and spoons so they're clean again. We can also wipe down the counter to make it sparkly, and then get our plates ready for when our yummy muffins are all done!

slides.text: You followed a recipe, measured ingredients, and baked muffins from scratch! That is real cooking. Share your muffins with pride!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a recipe, measure ingredients accurately using cups and spoons, and follow the sequence of steps?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! We followed the recipe, measured everything just right, and baked our own muffins! You were such a good baker, and now we get to share these yummy treats with everyone. High five!

parent_notes: Baking is arguably the most math-rich practical life activity. The child practices reading (the recipe), fractions (1/2 cup, 1/3 cup), measurement, sequencing, and following directions — all in service of creating something delicious. Montessori would note that the reward (eating muffins) is intrinsic and immediate, making the work deeply motivating. Point out the fractions naturally: 'This is a half cup — remember halves from our fraction work?' If the child is ready, double the recipe and discuss what happens to each measurement. The full cycle (prepare, bake, clean, serve) is essential.

title: Cursive Handwriting Introduction — Preparing the Hand
description: If the child shows readiness, this lesson introduces cursive letter formation beginning with pre-writing strokes: waves, loops, and connected curves. The child practices on a chalkboard before transitioning to paper, following the Montessori progression of large to small movement.
instructions:
1. 'You have been writing in print letters beautifully. Some writers also learn CURSIVE — a flowing, connected style of writing. Would you like to try?'
2. Demonstrate on the chalkboard: draw continuous wave patterns.
3. Child practices waves: smooth, even, filling the board.
4. Demonstrate loops: up-loop, down-loop, repeating.
5. Child practices loops across the board.
6. Connect them: waves that turn into loops.
7. Show one simple cursive letter: lowercase 'c' (same as print but with an entry stroke).
8. Child practices 'c' on the chalkboard, large.
9. Transfer to paper: practice waves, loops, and 'c' on lined paper with a pencil.
10. 'Cursive is like dancing with your pencil!'

slides.heading: Cursive Handwriting
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun new adventure we're going on! We're going to learn a super special way of writing called cursive, and we need to get our hands ready for it!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the chalkboard at child's standing height. Have paper and pencil ready for the transfer step.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our writing fun! We have a big chalkboard and chalk to make big drawings, and some special lined paper for when we write smaller. We also have a pencil, and maybe some bumpy letters to feel! Ask your grown-up to help you find them all so we can start.

slides.text: 'You are a wonderful print writer! Now let us explore a flowing style called cursive. In cursive, the letters connect and your pencil dances across the page without lifting.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You are already such a super writer with your regular letters! Now, we get to try a new way of writing called cursive, where all the letters hold hands and flow together like a dance. It's like your pencil is doing a happy little dance on the paper!

slides.text: 'First, let us warm up our hand with WAVES.' Demonstrate continuous wave patterns across the chalkboard. 'Your turn — smooth, even waves, like the ocean.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our hands ready to dance with some wiggly waves! Pretend your chalk is a little boat sailing on the ocean, making smooth, wavy lines all over the board. You can make them go up and down, up and down, just like the real ocean waves!

slides.text: 'Now LOOPS! Up and around, up and around...' Demonstrate repeating upward loops, then downward loops. 'Keep them even and flowing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's make some fun loops, like little happy circles going up and then down! We'll make them go round and round, up and down, and try to make them nice and even, like a beautiful ribbon. Keep them flowing, just like you did with the waves!

slides.text: 'Here is your first cursive letter: lowercase c. It starts with a little upswing, curves around — just like print c but with a connecting stroke at the beginning.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, here's our very first cursive letter, a lowercase 'c'! It looks a little bit like the 'c' you already know, but it has a special little party hat on the front to help it connect to the next letter. It starts with a little wiggle up, then curves around!

slides.prompt: Practice waves, loops, and the cursive letter 'c' on the chalkboard. Fill the board! Then try the same patterns on lined paper with your pencil. Which feels more natural?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to try all the fun things we learned! Let's make big waves and loops all over the chalkboard, and then try our new cursive 'c'. After that, we'll use our pencil to make smaller waves, loops, and 'c's on our special lined paper. See which one feels like the most fun for you!

slides.text: Cursive takes time and practice, just like print writing did. We will learn one or two new letters each week. Your hand is getting ready!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child produce smooth, continuous wave and loop patterns and form a recognizable cursive 'c'?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job getting your hand ready for cursive writing today! It takes practice, just like learning to ride a bike, and we'll learn more letters together soon. Your hand is getting stronger and ready for all the beautiful cursive words you'll write!

parent_notes: In Montessori schools, cursive is often taught BEFORE print because the flowing movements are more natural for young hands. In our homeschool context, we have taught print first (which is also a valid approach) and are now introducing cursive as the child shows readiness. Signs of readiness: strong pencil grip, legible print writing, good fine motor control. Start on the chalkboard — large arm movements are easier than small hand movements, and chalk provides natural resistance. There is no rush; some children take to cursive quickly while others need more time. The sandpaper letters (if available) provide the same tactile learning as for print letters. Never force cursive if the child is not interested — revisit later.

title: Shapes and Properties — Building and Classifying
description: The child builds shapes from craft sticks and classifies them by number of sides, creating a comprehensive shape reference chart. This hands-on construction reinforces understanding of geometric properties.
instructions:
1. 'Today we are going to BUILD shapes and discover their rules!'
2. Provide craft sticks and play dough (for corners). Child builds a triangle using 3 sticks.
3. 'How many sides? 3. How many corners? 3. A triangle always has 3 sides!'
4. Build: square (4 equal sticks), rectangle (2 long + 2 short), pentagon (5), hexagon (6).
5. Compare: 'What is the difference between a square and a rectangle? A square has all EQUAL sides!'
6. Sort shapes into groups: '3-sided shapes here, 4-sided shapes here, more-than-4 here.'
7. 'Shapes with 4 sides have a special family name: QUADRILATERALS. Quad means four!'
8. Create a shape reference chart with drawings, names, and properties.
9. Challenge: 'Can you build a shape with 8 sides? That is called an OCTAGON!'
materials_needed: Craft sticks (30+, various lengths if possible)
Play dough or clay for vertices

slides.heading: Building Shapes
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We are going to be super builders today and make all sorts of cool shapes. We'll learn about their sides and corners to see what makes them special.

slides.setup_instructions: Set out craft sticks sorted by length. Have play dough rolled into small balls for vertices. Prepare chart paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our building things ready! We have colorful sticks in different sizes, and sticky play dough to hold our shapes together. We also have a big paper and crayons to draw what we make. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these fun things!

slides.text: 'Let us be shape engineers! We will BUILD shapes from sticks and discover what makes each one special.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our super secret mission for today! We're going to be like shape engineers and build amazing shapes. We'll discover the special rules for each shape.

slides.text: 'Take 3 sticks and connect them with play dough at the corners. What shape did you make? A TRIANGLE! It has 3 sides and 3 corners — always.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's build our first shape! Grab three sticks and use the play dough to stick them together at the corners. See? You made a triangle! It has three sides and three pointy corners, and it will always have that many.

slides.text: 'Now use 4 EQUAL sticks. What shape? A SQUARE! Try 4 sticks where 2 are longer than the others — that is a RECTANGLE. Both have 4 sides, but the square is special because all sides are equal.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's try four sticks! If you use four sticks that are all the same size and stick them together, you make a square. If you use two long sticks and two short sticks, you make a rectangle. Both have four sides, but the square is special because all its sides are the same size!

slides.text: 'Shapes with 4 sides belong to a family called QUADRILATERALS. Quad means four! Try 5 sides: pentagon. Six sides: hexagon. Eight sides: octagon!'
slides.mascot_explanation: All shapes with four sides are in a special family called quadrilaterals, which means "four sides"! Let's try building shapes with more sides too, like a five-sided pentagon or a six-sided hexagon. We can even try an octagon with eight sides!

slides.prompt: Build one of each shape: triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon. Make a chart showing each shape, its name, and how many sides and corners it has.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to show off all the shapes we built! Let's make a big chart and draw each shape, write its name, and count its sides and corners. You get to be the artist and the mathematician!

slides.text: You built and classified shapes by their properties! Now you know: the number of sides defines the shape's name. Geometry is the mathematics of shapes!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and name at least 5 different polygons and state their number of sides?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job building and naming all those shapes! You learned that the number of sides tells us the name of the shape. Isn't it cool that we can know so much about shapes just by counting their sides?

parent_notes: Building shapes from sticks gives children a kinesthetic understanding that transcends drawing. They feel that a triangle needs exactly 3 sticks, that a square demands equal lengths, that pentagons are tricky to close. This is constructive geometry — building rather than just observing. The vocabulary (quadrilateral, pentagon, hexagon, octagon) may seem advanced, but Montessori found that young children absorb scientific vocabulary readily when paired with concrete experience. The prefix-based naming (penta=5, hexa=6, octa=8) connects to the number work they know. Keep the shape chart posted; the child will refer to it proudly.

title: Inventions and Inventors — People Who Solved Problems
description: The child learns about inventors and their inventions, connecting to the week's simple machines theme. By exploring how everyday inventions came to be, the child understands that inventions solve real problems and that anyone can be an inventor.
instructions:
1. 'Everything around us was INVENTED by someone! Someone had a problem and thought of a clever solution.'
2. Discuss familiar inventions and their stories:
   - The wheel (ancient Mesopotamia, ~3500 BCE)
   - The light bulb (Thomas Edison — tried 1,000+ times!)
   - Velcro (George de Mestral, inspired by burrs stuck to his dog)
   - The telephone (Alexander Graham Bell)
3. 'What do all inventors have in common? They noticed a problem and kept trying until they solved it!'
4. Connect to simple machines: 'The lever and ramp were some of the FIRST inventions!'
5. 'What problems do YOU notice in your life? What would you invent to solve them?'
6. Child brainstorms and draws an invention idea.
7. Present the invention: what it does, what problem it solves, what materials it needs.
materials_needed: Photos or illustrations of famous inventions

slides.heading: Inventions and Inventors
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! It says "Inventions and Inventors" and "People Who Solved Problems." That means we're going to learn about amazing people who thought of new things to help us!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare images of 4-5 inventions. If available, set up a simple timeline showing when each was invented.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, this slide shows us what we need for our fun inventing adventure! We've got pictures of super cool inventions, and we'll use paper and colorful pencils to draw our own amazing ideas. Maybe ask a grown-up to help you find these things!

slides.text: 'Look around this room. The light, the clock, the pencil, your shoes — everything was INVENTED! Someone somewhere thought it up for the first time.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look all around us! See the light that helps us see? And the clock that tells time? Even your comfy shoes were invented by someone! It’s like magic, but it's people being super smart and thinking up new things.

slides.text: 'The wheel was invented 5,000 years ago! Before that, people had to drag everything. Thomas Edison tried more than 1,000 times before his light bulb worked. He said: I have not failed, I have found 1,000 ways that do not work!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Did you know that the wheel is super, super old? Before that, people had to drag heavy things! And Mr. Edison tried so many times to make a light bulb, but he just kept trying and trying until he got it right. He's like a superhero for not giving up!

slides.text: 'George de Mestral went for a walk with his dog. Burrs got stuck to the dog's fur. He looked at them under a microscope and invented VELCRO! Nature inspired him!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a fun story! A man took his dog for a walk, and sticky little burrs got all over the dog's fur. He looked closely and thought, "Hmm, how can I make something that sticks like that?" And that's how he invented VELCRO!

slides.text: 'Simple machines were some of the first inventions. Levers and ramps helped ancient people build pyramids and move enormous stones! What problems do YOU notice that need solving?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Long, long ago, people invented simple things like ramps and levers to help them move really big rocks! That's so clever! Now, let's think: what things do YOU wish were easier? What problems do you see that need fixing?

slides.prompt: Think of a problem you have noticed — something that is hard to do or could be better. Design an invention to solve it! Draw your invention, label its parts, and explain what it does.
slides.mascot_explanation: It’s time to be an inventor! Think of something that bothers you, or something that could be better, and draw a special invention to fix it. What will your invention do, and what parts does it need? You can draw it right here!

slides.text: Every invention starts with a problem and a curious mind. You are already a problem-solver and a thinker — you could be an inventor too!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least 2 inventions and their purpose, and design an original invention idea?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a super inventor! You thought of amazing ideas and learned all about how people solve problems. Remember how you drew your special invention? You’re a real problem-solver, just like all the inventors we talked about!

parent_notes: This lesson connects science (simple machines), history (inventions timeline), and creative thinking (design challenges). The stories of inventors are inspiring because they demonstrate persistence, curiosity, and the value of failure — all themes that resonate with Montessori philosophy. Edison's famous quote about not failing but finding ways that do not work is a perfect growth mindset message. The invention design activity develops engineering thinking: identify a problem, brainstorm solutions, design a prototype. If the child is excited, provide recycled materials to actually build their invention!

title: Read-Aloud: Library Lion by Michelle Knudsen
description: Reading 'Library Lion' by Michelle Knudsen, a story about a lion who loves the library and learns about rules, kindness, and when it's okay to break rules.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'A lion in a library! What do you think will happen?'
2. Read aloud with different voices for the librarian and Mr. McBee.
3. Discuss the rules: 'Why are there rules in the library?'
4. When the lion roars, ask: 'Was it okay to break the rule this time? Why?'
5. Talk about when rules are important and when helping someone matters more.
6. Connect to your own library visits.

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the cover of our storybook for today. It's called "Library Lion," and it's all about a lion who goes to the library. We're going to read it together and see what happens!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready in a cozy reading spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our special story time, we need our book, "Library Lion." If you have a stuffed lion friend, you can bring them too, so they can listen to the story with us! Let's find a super comfy spot to read.

slides.text: Cover: 'Look at this lion walking into the library! What do you think the librarian will say?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely at the cover! We see a lion walking right into a library. What do you think the librarian, the person who works at the library, will say to the lion? Maybe she'll be surprised!

slides.text: Read with expression — Miss Merriweather's firm voice, Mr. McBee's worried tone, the lion's gentle nature.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, when we read our story, I'm going to use funny voices for the people and the lion. I'll make the librarian sound a certain way and the lion sound gentle, so the story is extra fun to listen to.

slides.text: Discuss: 'Why did the lion roar? Was it okay to break the no-roaring rule? Why or why not?'
slides.mascot_explanation: In our story, the lion roars, but there's a rule about not roaring in the library. We'll talk about *why* the lion roared and if it was okay to break that rule, or if helping someone was more important.

slides.prompt: Let's make our own library rules! What are three good rules for our reading space? Draw a picture of a lion in a library.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to think about rules for our own reading space. What are three good rules we can have? Then, we'll draw a picture of our lion friend in the library.

slides.text: 'Sometimes the most important rule is to help someone who needs it. The lion knew that.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why the lion broke the rule and whether it was right?
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how the lion roared even though it wasn't allowed? We learned that sometimes, helping a friend is the most important thing. Can you tell me why the lion broke the rule?

parent_notes: This story explores rules, community belonging, and the nuance of when compassion overrides rules. It's a wonderful springboard for discussing grace and courtesy — a core Montessori concept. The library setting also reinforces love of books and reading spaces.
